characters: BECAUSE THAT IS WHAT HAPPENED TO MY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An idyllic American factory. There's a huge, long lawn in front. A Reynolds Extract sign in brick with flowers/landscaping around it, sits near the entrance. We see from the number of cars in the parking lot that it's company of about 50 - 75 employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in a manufacturing area of an assembly-line production. It's a big room full of intricate machines, h vats of different colored extract and other food flavorin products, conveyor belts, bottling machines, etc. It has high ceiling with offices on the second floor that have b windows overlooking this manufacturing area. We PAN up to the main office.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE OFFICE
dialogues.text: JOEL REYNOLDS, head of the company, mid-thirties, is on t phone with his friend DEAN. DEAN (v.o.) You should come by tonight. Half price well drinks while the game's going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always give me free drinks though. DEAN (v.o.) Oh yeah. Well come by anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?... Might as well. No action going on at my house, that's for sure. DEAN (v.o.) Really? The wife out of town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I just haven't been laid in a month.
DEAN (v.o.) You guys having problems or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is pretty much normal these days... As CREDITS continue, camera PULLS OUT, back down to the manufacturing area, past a big vat of orange extract, dow through various stages of assembly line production, then follows several bottles of orange extract moving past HECTOR, a Mexican immigrant employee in his thirties. The camera stops on him. Talking to Hector is STEP, a short, beady-eyed Charles-Manson-looking guy with a beard and mustache. Step is in his forties. He makes everything he says sound as macho and important as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get this job through Manpower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started here with Manpower too. Started out on the line just like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only I did better... 40 crates a day.  Beat. Hector is not quite sure what he's talking about. STEP continues telling his tale in such a way that the on polite reaction would be one of total amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best sorter in here. That's why they made me full time with benefits. I'll probably be floor manager this year. A FEW FEET AWAY we see RORY, a stocky indie-rock geek, wi too many tatoos, hair shaved on the side with a ponytail, lots of bad piercings, wearing baggy shorts with lots of pockets and some kind of gothy T-shirt -- a look that oug to be out of style by now.

Rory is putting stickers on boxes with a sticker gun. He flips the sticker gun around unnecessarily between each application, adding a few unnecessary moves/motions, slap each box when he's done, generally making the activity lo like more of a skill than it actually is. He approaches S and Hector, pulling out some fliers from his many pockets

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands them each a flier) My band's playing this Friday, come check us out. Hector looks down at the flier. It's xeroxed with fifties clip-art, cut out letters and the name of the band, "God' Cock". Hector just looks at it confused, not knowing much English, not sure what he's supposed to be doing with the flier. AT THE END OF THE LINE, where boxes are loaded onto palle sits MARY, 58 years old, wearing a 15-year-old pair of ac wash jeans, and an oversized tweety-bird T-shirt, fanny p and dayglow yellow triangle-shaped earrings. She's pear- shaped with short hair. She's bitter and bossy, always shaking her head at everyone. She sits on a stool with a clipboard, looks over her glasses at Hector, shaking her head. She talks to Gabriella, a Hispanic woman in her forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that... That new guy. He's holding us up. It's not my job to tell them to hold the line either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then Joel's gonna come yell at us, cuz he's not doing his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folds her arms, fed up) I'm just gonna sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna shut it off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna hold the line. If they're not gonna do their job, why should I do mine. Mary sits there, arms folded, lips pursed, refusing to pa the conveyor belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel is still on the phone with Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't get home before about 8:00, she puts on the sweatpants and once the sweatpants are on, it's over -- I get nothing. (notices something down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. I'm gonna have to call you back. Joel hangs up and runs downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MANUFACTURING FLOOR
dialogues.text: Boxes start to accumulate and fall off the end of the lin Step sees this, runs to shut off the line, yelling at Mar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are YOU doing?! (pointing at Hector) What is he doing? A YELLING/BICKERING MATCH breaks out between Mary, Step, and Gabriella. Joel runs over, shuts off the conveyor bel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Now, what's the problem? They all erupt in more BICKERING AND FINGER POINTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Okay, everyone settle down. Now Mary. Hector here is new okay? It's gonna take him a couple of days, maybe his English isn't so good. You gotta be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I was tryin' to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Step, if you wanna be Floor Manager, this is the kind of thing you're going to have to deal with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now Step, Rory, Hector, let's get this cleaned up, and get rolling again. We can't afford to fall behind today. Joel walks away. People resume their posts. Mary starts right back up with Gabriella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that? We always get the blame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits in his swivel chair, looking down at the produc floor, shaking his head. BRIAN, Joel's second in command, walks in. He's a little older than Joel, neatly trimmed beard, aviator glasses, and a bit of a gut. He wears a Reynold's Extract golf shirt and Khaki pants. He walks ov to the window, joins Joel, looking down at the employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... They're like a bunch of  goddamned children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Sorry I missed the drama; I was showing boy-genius down there how to back up a forklift. ANGLE ON Rory, driving the forklift, handing out a flier he passes someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his whole career, driving that damn forklift. You'd think he'd wanna learn how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess he's got that band  he's in too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgust at the word

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Band", ugh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet dollars to donuts he sucks at that too. Then you got ah... (tries to remember her name but can't) Dinkus down there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the other one -- what's-her- face -- she asked me -- or rather "axed" me -- for more personal days. Just like that. I told her maybe if she figures out how to fill out the time sheets correctly I'll give her more personal days... (Off Joel's look) Don't worry, she will never fill out her time sheets correctly. Joel looks down at the production floor. Joel's POV:  ANGLE ON: Mary and Step bickering. Step walks off. Mary a Gabrielle shaking their heads and yapping like a couple o old hens.

dialogues.speaker: JOEL, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Look at 'em... I am so sick of baby sitting these assholes. (looks at his watch) I better get going... Joel leaves in a hurry, mumbling something about  "sweatpants."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel drives home, in a hurry, checking his dashboard cloc It's an upscale neighborhood of McMansions in a town like Lincoln Nebraska. He turns a corner, slows down suddenly when he sees something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN, a middle-aged, overweight, annoying guy is going to the street to get his mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself, praying) Please go back inside... Please just turn around.. .Come on...don't notice me...
It's too late. Nathan turns, sees Joel's car and waves, t crosses the street to Joel's driveway and waits to talk t him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Joel pulls into his driveway as Nathan flags him down. Jo begrudgingly rolls down the passenger side window so Nath can talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there Joel! Glad I caught ya... Nathan settles in like he's going to be there a while, leaning with his arms folded, hanging inside the car, trapping Joel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How've ya been? I left you a message last week. I don't know if you got it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, actually Nathan, I'm kind of in a hurry here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? You been busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in fact... (checks his watch) I should go right now actually. I gotta call the office before they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, real quick while I got ya here -- what're you guys doing November 17th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I don't ah... (realizes his should fake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually we're going to be out of town that weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait a minute -- I'm sorry, I meant the 7th. Yeah, November 7th. You'll be in town then right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah...Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. There's this dinner Leslie and I are going to. It's an annual thing -- we do it every year with the Rotary Club -- it's for charity. It's just a whole lot of fun, and we wanted to invite you and Suzie to be our guests at our table. It's--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I ah... I just don't think that's something we're gonna want to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Why not? It's a lot of fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Suzie doesn't really like going to stuff like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we wouldn't know anybody there. She get's kind of uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no -- It's not like that. She won't be uncomfortable. I guarantee it. No, it's not like that at all. It's not formal or anything. Trust me. It's just a real loose bunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you what. Why don't we do this -- I'll go ahead and get tickets, since they're gonna sell out fast. You talk to Suzie. See what she says. Like I say, she won't be uncomfortable at all. Maybe I'll have Leslie give her a call -- you know how it is when the wives talk, heh heh-- Joel is about to snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, why don't we talk about this later. (looks at his watch) I gotta make this call before they leave. Joel pulls away, forcing Nathan to raise off the window s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I just gotta make this call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel pulls the car in, steps out and is shocked to see Na right there in his garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I almost forgot -- the tickets are forty dollars a plate. I know that's a little steep, but the food is fantastic and it's for a good cause. So that'd be eighty dollars total. There's no tax or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, look Nathan, I really gotta get inside and make this call. Let's talk about this another time. Joel has his finger on the button to shut the garage door waiting for Nathan to get out. Nathan stops, just inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and if you need us to look out for the house or anything when you go out of town -- Joel's finger still on the garage door button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just let us know. Where you guys going anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, just sort of a vacation. Look, I gotta run. Joel hits the button and the door starts going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then. We'll see ya. Nathan finally steps out of the garage. Joel breaths a hu sigh of relief. Then,

dialogues.speaker: THE GARAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: As it gets halfway down, we see Nathan's legs, heading ba towards the door. Nathan leans down into frame as the doo goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Joel one more thing-- Joel lets the door shut on him, and bolts into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel walks into the living room just as his wife, SUZIE, enters from the bedroom pulling on her SWEATPANTS. A look disappointment on Joel's face. Suzie is a decent looking woman, about Joel's age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, that Nathan won't shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what an asshole. I don't even go into the front yard anymore. That wife of his is even worse.
Suzie plops down on the couch looking tired and pissed of Joel sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get a new pool cleaner.I don't think that asshole checked the chlorine levels again like I asked him too... Joel puts his arm around her, caresses her shoulder. She doesn't seem to notice as he starts getting fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .and every time he is here, he goes on and on about some problem with the goddamn filter, and I have no idea what he's talking about... Delayed reaction -- she notices Joel is getting frisky. H gets closer, starts kissing her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah,...Joel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's just... I'm a little tired, and, I don't know, it's the middle of the week...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the middle of the week. It's Monday. Why can't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday? (Freezes, suddenly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idol! Suzie jumps up with newfound energy, runs for the remote turns on the TV. Joel just sits there.
Suzie plops down in a Barcalounger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry honey. Maybe this weekend. Joel leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Quick scene of Joel trying to masturbate (off screen of course), but he's too distracted by the sounds of a bad o of-tune Idol audition blaring through the wall.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot. A sports bar that's part of a Holiday Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits at the bar. DEAN, the owner of the bar, late forties, and an old friend of Joel's, sits behind the bar a stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get a house with a bathroom that's doesn't share a wall with the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you do that in another bathroom. You've got three of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would look suspicious. We never use those other bathrooms... Maybe if I had some insulation put in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insulation?... All I know is, you shouldn't move man; you've got a nice house. I mean you've got the American dream really -- you own your own company. I can't believe you used to bar back for me here, and now you've got all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what do I have really? It's a big pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always working; can't stop or the whole place will fall apart. And what good does it do me anyway? I don't get laid. That stock guy with the shitty band that works for me probably gets laid more than I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to help) Yeah, but he probably lives in a crappy apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I'd move into a crappy apartment if the bathroom wasn't right next to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDY, a girl in her early twenties, is at the counter looking at a new Gibson hollow-body electric guitar -- on the really nice ones. The price tag says $3,950. She's beautiful and sexy and all that, but there's something vulnerable and sweet about her as well. Two SALESMEN, typical music store employees -- long-haire goateed, nerdy cocky guitar-hacks are giving her way too attention. It's clear that they don't usually have women this hot in their store. They practically stumble over ea other trying to help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's expensive but it's sweet... Are you familiar with the Gibson humbucking pickups?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sorry. I don't play. It's for my Dad actually -- for his fiftieth birthday. My sisters and I are all pitching in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, that's nice... Your Dad would love these humbuckings. They really kick ass. An annoyed MALE CUSTOMER has been waiting behind Cindy, trying to get some help, but he might as well be invisibl He tries to address Salesman #2, off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... I just have a quick question... Salesman #2 is oblivious, never takes his eyes off Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what kind of music did he play? Both Salesmen's eyes are glued to Cindy as Male Customer finally gets sick of waiting and storms off into the keyb room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he played like, jazz or something. I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well this is an excellent jazz guitar. It's what Pat Metheny plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your Dad into Metheny at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know who that is. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's like, a totally kickass fusion guitarist. Are you into fusion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know much about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I play fusion guitar so... Just curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, do they come in any other colors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean different finishes? There's a sunburst finish we might have in stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, do you wanna see it? I'll go get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or I could go. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh totally./ No prob!/ I'll show you the case it comes with too. The salesmen practically trip over each other, going into back to find the other guitar. Cindy stands there alone for a beat. She looks around. Th casually picks up the four-thousand dollar guitar and wal out the front door with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy walks a few yards over to her car, a ' 92 Tercel, p the guitar in the trunk, gets in and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two Salesmen return -- one carrying the sunburst-fini guitar and the other with the hard-shell case. They look around, notice she's gone. They stand there for a beat, disappointed, before they realize what just happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit!...

dialogues.speaker: THE GIBSON
dialogues.text: They run out the front door, but Cindy is long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel is at his desk. Brian comes in, excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna believe this. Remember the guy from General Mills that called a while back? Talking like he wanted to buy us out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said he wasn't serious; he was just sniffing around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well he's serious now. He just made an offer -- I mean a real offer this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It must be part of some bigger strategic move, because it's over market value I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... Joel lets it sink in. He walks over to the window, lookin down on the production floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could unload all this... I could probably retire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, yeah, there's a lot of details to work out, but this could be great. They'll be calling back next week, what should I tell them? Joel looks down, sees Mary sitting with her arms folded, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em hell yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits with her arms folded, refusing to hold the line

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already warned him. This is the last time. I'm just gonna sit here. In SLOW MOTION, we see:

- The first box falls off the end of the assembly line, bottles shatter. - Rory, carrying some boxes slips on the broken bottles o goopey extract, falls and slides into an aisle. - A forklift stops suddenly to avoid hitting Rory, causin huge stack of pallets to fall off. - Quick shot of Mary shaking her head in slow-motion. - Just as Step rounds a corner to see what's going on, th pallets land on a bunch of pipes and high-pressure valves which burst open sending a piece of shrapnel flying acros the room heading straight for - STEP'S CROTCH. The shrapnel heads straight for his genitalia, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step is on a stretcher being loaded into a MEDIVAC helico by a couple of EMS guys. Step moans in pain as Joel tries comfort him. A small crowd of employees watch. ANGLE ON Mary in the crowd, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. That's what happens when you don't pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits at the bar, on a cell phone. Dean sits behind t bar on a stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the person on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh... Alright. Let me know if you hear anything else. He hangs up, talks to Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's definitely lost one of 'em. They think they might be able to re-attach the other one, but they're not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Wow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'm not sure how it happened, but we have a great safety record and we comply with all the safety codes so... it was just a freak accident. There'll be an investigation of some kind I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you have insurance for that kind of thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Of course. In fact, he'll probably get a huge settlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I would think so. I mean, it's your balls... Beat, as they contemplate the profundity of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy it really makes you stop and think about how fragile we are -- especially our balls. They're just hanging there in a little sack between our legs. At any moment they could be cut off forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. And your balls are really important man. Your balls are everything. What kind of life would you have with no testicles? Can you imagine that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Dean, my life wouldn't be much different than it is now actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for once every three months when I have sex with my wife. In fact, I might even be better off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Three months? I thought you said it was once a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did? I must've been lying. I don't know... Maybe things'll get better when I sell the company. I'll be around more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope so. That would suck... I get laid all the time. (off Joel's reaction) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it's all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sexual frustration is bad news... You know what you oughtta do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get some Xanax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xanax? Isn't that for anxiety?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah it is, but I find it's good for just about any phsychological problem. I mean, basically it just makes you feel good, so it sort of works for anything. I even take it when I have a cold. It's probably great for sexual frustration. Want me to get you some?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else is good? Codeine cough syrup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just good. Joel looks at Dean for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you on something now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Well, I guess I took some Vicodin this morning. But that was just 'cause I was hung-over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot, a pawn shop in a strip mall. Cindy's c parked out in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy is at the counter, the Gibson guitar we saw earlier in front of her. A PAWN SHOP GUY is counting out money. H pauses, looks around, then speaks sympathetically to her.

dialogues.speaker: PAWN SHOP GUY
dialogues.text: Um, you know, I'm really not supposed to say this... but since this belonged to your father, and since he passed away and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could probably get a better deal at a music store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's okay. Thanks. But I just kind of wanna get it over with, you know? It's kind of hard for me.

dialogues.speaker: PAWN SHOP GUY
dialogues.text: I understand. He looks around to see if his boss is watching, then coun off a FEW MORE TWENTIES, feeling sorry for her.
PAWN SHOP GUY (cont'd) Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy puts the money in her wallet, along with a driver's license. CLOSE ON THE WALLET. Cindy shuffles through three or four different driver's licenses. On one, her name says MISTY PATTERSON. It's a Kansas license. She takes another one out from Colorado, with the name CINDY METZLER on it and puts that in front, then puts the wallet away. A newspaper sits on the front seat. Something grabs her attention.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: We see an article about Step's accident. There's a pictur of Step being taken away on the stretcher. Cindy starts reading the article, with growing interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She scans the article, zeroing in on certain words, ".. .potentially big settlement..." "...no testicles..." "several million dollars" then back to "no testicles" the quickly back and forth several times -- "million dollars" testicles" "million dollars" "no testicles" ON CINDY'S FACE - A look of determination. She looks one more time at the name under the picture -- Don "Step" Wilkenson, then zeroes in on the words "Reynold's Extract She starts the car and speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits with Brian. Brian has a clipboard, going over t day's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So obviously Step's not coming back anytime soon. I had to hire a couple temps. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. How is Step?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better. They say he's going home in a couple of days. Speaking of which, the guys at General Mills heard about this whole Step thing. They're worried. If Step decides to sue us -- beyond the insurance settlement -- it could be a serious liability. They don't want to make an offer until this thing has settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? They think it's that big  of a liability?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah. Don't you? I mean, think about it. Imagine if you asked a bunch of jurors how much you'd have to pay 'em to cut their balls off? I mean, I wouldn't let someone cut my balls off for a billion dollars. Seriously -- unless there were some kind of really expensive operation that could give you artificial balls or something. Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I wouldn't worry. He says he's not going to sue us. Says he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "don't want somethin' fer nothin "' and "What's right is right." If we can just get him to sign something to that effect we should be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, Step sure is being mellow  about all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I think when you lose your balls it mellows you out. You don't get as pissed off and aggressive about things. I know it's true for horses, and bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, it sure does make you think..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, guess who asked for  a raise today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to someone downstairs) Dinkus. Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, you call everyone here "Dinkus." I don't know who you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Forklift-Dinkus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... I thought you call him "boy-  genius."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well boy-genius asked for a raise. I said, "are you kidding? You nearly got someone killed last week," and then he blamed it on Dinkus over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Brian, you really ought to  learn the employees' names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was thinking about that, but hey, if this deal goes through next week, I won't have to. It's not like I'm gonna be inviting Dinkus and Boy-Genius over for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel stands on one side of his office looking down throug long window overlooking the manufacturing area. Dean come in, walks over to the window, looks down at the productio floor with Joel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man. What's goin' o-- Whoa! DEAN'S POV: It's CINDY, now working down on the floor, on the assembley line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! Who's she? Is she new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's a temp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a tramp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No a temp. Quit staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, she's hot! Way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I didn't hire her. She came here through Manpower, like everybody else. They just sent her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manpower, huh? Maybe I should give them a call. You don't usually have girls anywhere near that hot working here. What's the deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I guess it makes sense though if you think about it. Hot girls need a job just as much as anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks for a second) Do they really?... Huh... You just don't see 'em here. Usually your temps look like winos. And they're guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna hear something really weird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came on to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way! Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, I'm pretty sure. I could be wrong, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm sure she did. Are you kidding? You could have any girl down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Dude, you're the big shot here. You're the king of... What do you call that shit you make here again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extract. And spray-dried flavoring, and we're branching out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're the Extract King man. You could have any girl here. I mean, I wouldn't want most of 'em, but her... Way to go Joel. Dean looks down at manufacturing area, taking it all in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how did she come on to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, first she started asking me about what happened to Step and all that stuff -- you know, just sort of making conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it really seemed like she was flirting with me, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, she just sort of asked me out... I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you see that guy down there by the fork lift? ANGLE ON Rory, the indi-rock guy with tattoos, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His band is playing somewhere, at some party this weekend, and she asked me if I wanted to go with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. So, you gonna do anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No. No way. I couldn't live with myself if I cheated on Suzie... It'd be nice if I got laid at home once in a while though...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still staring at her) Man, she is fine. You mind if I hit that then? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do sort of... We see a COMMOTION down on the floor. Mary runs out of th Women's locker room SCREAMING AND YELLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary runs over to where Hector is working, hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My purse is stolen! It's gone! (pointing at Hector) He did it! He stole my purse!
Brian runs over and stands between them, trying to calm M down, but she keeps ranting. Hector looks confused and worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't hold on! I'll call the cops!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused, frightened) What? I don'... No comprende...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Espera un momento Hector. Tu sabes donde esta su... uh, purse? ANGLE ON CINDY, watching the whole thing-- completely unfazed.Joel rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a second. Calm down Mary. How do you know it was stolen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone! That's how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what did it look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was black with a fur, leopard style border... As Mary describes the purse, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy sits in her parked car, going through the purse Mar just described. She takes some cash, puts it in her pocke then finds what she's looking for -- the address book. ANGLE ON ADDRESS BOOK. Cindy turns to the Ws and finds Step Wilkenson. She notes his address. She starts the car and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy sits and waits, listening to the radio. It's a very blue-collar neighborhood. She's about three houses away f Step's house, keeping an eye on it. After a beat, Step limps out of the house, walks over to pickup truck, painfully gets in, and leaves. Cindy starts the car and follows from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step wheels his shopping cart into one of the checkout li He uses the cart as a crutch to help him walk. Cindy gets line behind him. She only has one item, a bottle of Reynold's Orange Extract. Step notices her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can go ahead of me if that's all you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. (holds up extract bottle) I can't believe I'm buying this stuff -- I work at the factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I work there too. Or, ah, I used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You're kidding! I just started there. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go by Step. Yeah, I'm the fastest sorter there... As Cindy and Step get to know each other we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel enters the living room. He first sees the sweatpants then sees Suzie is sound asleep on the couch. He sighs, t turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits at the bar talking to Dean. Joel is drinking so kind of hard liquor, getting a buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of it Dean. I'm sick of being turned down in my own house by my own wife. We're turning into one of those brother-sister couples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh...Now that you mention it, you guys kind of look alike too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a drink) Maybe things will be better after I sell the company... Or maybe it's just going to mean more time to sit around and contemplate not getting laid. Dean nods sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that girl at work? She still into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... she was really coming on to me. She gave me her phone number and everything. Told me to call her if I wanted to go to that party. Can you believe that? And there's nothing I can do about it, but just be sexually frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some Xanax if you want it. Like I say, that always works for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe you should call that girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't. I can't cheat on Suzie. I just gotta power through it until I'm so old that I can't get it up anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about if Suzie cheated on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... I hadn't even thought of that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish she would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish she would cheat on you? Wouldn't that bother you? Joel thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't think it would actually. (occuring to him) I guess that's weird huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a little weird. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But see, then I could do something about all this sexual frustration, without feeling guilty about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she would cheat on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. Hmm... Maybe if she were really tempted she would. Like if some really studly guy came on to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying she would probably cheat on you if she was put in temptation's way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you oughtta do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna do any drugs Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. Check this out -- If you really wish your wife would cheat on you, it's not that hard to make it happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hire a gigolo to have an affair with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. I know a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know a gigolo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know a gigolo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy Brad. He comes in here all the time. He's a friend of Vic's. You could hire him to have an affair with Suzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Dean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You said you wouldn't care if she cheated on you. Then you'd be free to go out with that Cindy chick and get your ya-yas out -- with no guilt. Problem solved. (proud of himself) Man, what a great idea. Joel just shakes his head at the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, maybe I will try some of that Xanax. Dean reaches down under the cash register and whips out a little box and pulls out a pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step's truck is parked out at a lake in the country. He a Cindy sit next to each other on the tailgate, looking at stars, talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just believe that what's right is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right Step, and what's right is for you to send a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to send a message so that a horrible accident like this never happens to anyone else ever again. That's what's right. And the way you do that is to take them to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Step... That's why I called a lawyer for you -- that guy on all the bus stop benches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Adler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm... I just want you to do what's right Step. They start cuddling, kissing. Cindy pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Step, your doctor said you shouldn't get aroused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was your lawyer, but he talked to your doctor. And your doctor said it's very important not to get aroused until after the trial... I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay... You're so good to me Cindy. They start cuddling again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Step, you're getting me turned on, I'm getting you turned on... I better just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel is starting to look really tweaked as the drug-alcoh combination begins to kick in. Dean is examining a pill under the cash register light, trying to read the small print. He looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit... Do you remember what color that pill I gave you was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. I don't think it was Xanax. I think that might've been Ritalin... Or "Special K."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling the buzz) Ah, who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, ah, Special K is a horse tranquilizer, kinda has a weird effect when people take it but... well, don't worry about it... You might not want to drink too much more though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to slur his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that thing you were talking about? About the gigolo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it would be wrong to do that? I mean morally wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with full authority) Oh nooo. Definitely not. What could be morally wrong about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if she doesn't want to go for it, she doesn't have to. And if she does, then she's the one who sinned, and then it's perfectly morally right for you to go out and boff whoever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess you're right. I can't think of anything morally wrong about it either. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this guy, he's a friend of yours? What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad. You want me to give him a call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's kinda weird even talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is no big deal Joel. I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, you can't lose. Just say you're hiring him to come clean the pool or something. See what happens. If she doesn't go for it, then at least you know you're doing the right thing by being faithful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess you're right... I don't know. It's crazy. Dean pours Joel another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Have another drink. Think about it... You know what? Why don't I just call Brad and see what he has to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. What the hell. Joel takes a big swig of liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean and Joel are talking with BRAD, the gigolo. He's you blonde, super good-looking, but clearly a complete airhea Joel looks really messed up now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's two-hundred dollars then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, two-hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah, but don't forget, I'm getting ten percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, so you're a pimp now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're called "pimps" when it's with male prostitutes, okay. There's some other word for it -- it's not a "john," but it's something like that. Besides, I'm the one who hooked all this up. And don't worry 'cuz it's coming out of Brad's money anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's two-hundred dollars then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-hundred and twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I have a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Brad looks at Joel, deeply concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So like, are you gonna, like, watch or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no. God no! It's not like that. I won't even be there. I'll be at work. Remember? We already talked about this. Brad looks blank, like he's not getting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you'll do, is come to my house pretending to be the new pool cleaner. Then you simply try to seduce my wife. Okay? If she doesn't respond, you simply clean the pool and leave. That's all. It's that simple. Hold on Brad for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, uh, you're not gonna touch my ass or anything...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! Try to pay attention okay? I will not be there. I will be at work. You come over to my house while I'm not there, posing as the new pool cleaner and then try to seduce her... Brad finally makes a breakthrough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, I see. Sorry man. Yeah, yeah. I get it now. You're not even gonna be there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... cool. No problem. This is gonna be great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, she might not go for it-- Brad starts to get a little too excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is gonna be cool! I can hardly wait! Awesome. Hey man, if you know anyone else who needs -- you know -- what I do, like you know, lonely housewives and shit, maybe you could tell 'em about me, you know... Joel looks on with growing concern as Brad can't seem to talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuz like, I figure if I did a few jobs and I was, like, really good? Then maybe they'd tell their friends, you know, and they'd give me a... what do you call those things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Referrals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah, those things. Then those women could tell more women and then it'd be like I was, like, uh... branching or..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Networking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, networking! Totally. Then if I got enough of 'em, maybe I could quit my landscaping job and do this full time. That would be awesome! Cause I hate landscaping. I like getting laid a lot better, and my boss is a total dick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel and Dean are at Dean's car, trying to say goodbye to Brad, who still won't shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I say, if your wife has any housewife friends who might-- Dean finally puts his foot down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you've said that a few times now Brad. Go on to your car. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Cool. Like I say--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight Brad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. See you later. Brad finally leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me drive you home. You're in no condition to drive. Joel stumbles into Dean's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this guy Dean? He acts like he's never done this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. He does it all the time. Don't worry. He just gets a little excited sometimes. He's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He sure doesn't seem too bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well, what do you excpect? He's a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A break room with a kitchen. Joel is badly hungover. He looks like he's about to throw up as he reaches into the cupboard above the sink, downs a couple of aspirin, then drops some alka-seltzer in to a glass of water. Cindy com in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you had one of those nights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was I? Joel nods, tries to grin and look cool as he takes a sip his alkaseltzer. Then his eyes go wide, he almost does a spit-take as something suddenly dawns on him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! He runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel grabs the phone and dials frantically. Dean answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Joel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God you're home. Ah,... did that really happen last night? I mean, did we go through with it -- with that gigolo stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yeah. As far as I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! What was I thinking?! We gotta call it off. Right now. Can you call that guy, Brad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'll pay him anyway, whatever, just don't come over. God, what was I thinking?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll call him. No problem... Oh wait a second. I don't think I have his number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I thought you called him last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I got his number from Vic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well get it from him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vic doesn't have a phone right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! I'll try information. What's Brad's last name? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... it's something like,... I think it's a Mexican name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mexican?! The guy's got blonde hair and blue eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought it was weird too -- a guy like that with a Mexican last name... It's like Lopez, or Sanchez or something. Joel looks at his watch. It's 11:15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! Joel hangs up the phone, and rushes out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel, we gotta talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yeah, it's kind of important -- kind of really important. It's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel rushes past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now! We FOLLOW Joel as he rushes past his SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me Joel? There's a Brad Chavez on line one for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, I-- Joel stops suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad Chavez. He said he's done with the job you guys talked about at your house? Do you want me to take a message? Joel looks pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, no... He's the ah, pool cleaner. I better take that. Joel goes back in his office. HOLD on Brian, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel stares at the phone for a beat then picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, is this Joel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Brad. Mission accomplished dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I mean it worked. She totally went for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What're you...? (looks at his watch) You weren't even supposed to be there for another 45 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh really? I forgot what time you guys said, and I was so excited about it, I just went over there. Joel sits down, freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reality setting in) So you mean she actually ah... you guys...?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yup. It was easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy? What do you mean "easy"?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't mean easy like she was easy -- like she was a slut or anything. I just mean it wasn't hard to get her to... Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Tell me. Tell me how it happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna hear everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, she let me in, so I went back like I was cleaning the pool...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Brad's dopey narration continues, we see the story he' telling. It plays out like a bad soft-porn flick on Cinem We see Brad wiping the side of the pool with a rag.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .I don't know anything about pool cleaning, so I was just faking it. She was in her bathing suit... Suzie comes out and lies on one of the reclining chairs.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: .So I struck up a conversation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a really nice house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it your Dad's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, you look so young to be living in a house this nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any sunscreen? I forgot mine.
Brad's dopey narration comes back in...

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I thought that was pretty smart of me -- to ask her to borrow sunscreen. See, 'cuz that way, once she gave me some, I could ask her if she wanted some too, and rub some on her back, instead of just coming out and asking her to rub some on her. Pretty smooth huh?... We see Brad rubbing lotion on Suzie's back as she lies fa down on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Once I was rubbing the sunscreen on her, the rest was easy... We see Brad's hands working their way down Suzie's back. Just as they start to move down towards her butt, Joel interrupts, YANKING US OUT OF THE FLASHBACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay that's enough! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to hear anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Okay, cool. Hey, like I say, if you know of anyone else, or if you ever need me to do it again--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! No. Look, I gotta go. Bye. Joel hangs up the phone and falls back into his chair, in state of shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to himself) Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel drives home from work. He still looks freaked out. H notices something ahead, and suddenly SLAMS ON THE BREAKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit ! JOEL'S POV: Nathan, the guy across the street is in his f yard, puttering around with the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not today... Joel puts the car in reverse, starts to pull behind a par car in an attempt to hide, but Nathan notices him, waves crosses the street. Joel reluctantly pulls ahead to his driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm kind of busy actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well I won't keep you. I just wanted to let you know, I got those tickets to that dinner we talked about on the 7th. I think I told you they were forty dollars a piece, but it turns out it's a tad more this year -- fifty-five -- so if I could go ahead and just get a check from you guys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, ah, we can't go. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is the 7th. You said you're going out of town on the 17th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but remember, I told you we didn't really want to go to this thing. Nathan looks dumbfounded. Joel is about to snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I already bought the tickets. I know you said something about her feeling uncomfortable, but, like I say, she won't feel uncomfortable at all -- I guarantee it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 NATHAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a whole lot of fun. You guys'll have a great time. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I gotta get going. NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then... Joel starts to pull away. NATHAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, one more thing -- Joel just keeps driving, almost knocking Nathan over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel and Suzie are eating dinner. Suzie has a glow about her, looking better than ever -- relaxed, satisfied, etc. Joel's has a quietly pissed off demeanor. They eat in silence for a beat. SUZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... How's work? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sucks. SUZIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? What's wrong? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Suzie looks a little puzzled. They keep eating in silence for a beat. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel well. I'm going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the window in his office, Joel watches Cindy working down on the production floor. Cindy looks up, they make e contact for a brief moment. She gives him a flirtacious w Joel waves back. Then Rory comes by, starts talking to Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're in a band? RORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Actually, I'm in five bands right now. But Godscock is basically the same four guys as Fighthead, but Fighthead's more of a thrash/skatepunk thing. Godscock is more melodic stuff. Cindy nods politely. Rory thinks she's interested. RORY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you comin' Friday? CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, definitely. (looks at her watch) Ooh, I gotta go. Dentist appointment. RORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Cindy leaves. ANGLE ON Mary, on the other side of the room, watching th She talks to Gabriella. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, there he goes again, slowing us down. (RE: CINDY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she's a good sorter. They need to hire more people like her. GABRIELLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so nice too. Hector walks by. Mary just shakes her head. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe he's still working here. You know Silvia can't find her wallet. Thinks it was stolen. And guess who was in the locker room last? Hector. They both look at Hector and shake their heads in disgust
MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I could get a job at Southwest Airlines. My Niece works there. I'd get better benefits than we get here too. GABRIELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm hmm. I could get a job at Gemco. You think they would put up with this stuff at Gemco? Mmm mmn. They run a tight ship. MARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel's POV of Mary and Gabrielle, yacking self-righteousl Joel looks on with disgust... JOEL (TO HIMSELF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good riddance... Brian steps in, taps on the door. BRIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a second? I think we might have a big problem here. I'm not sure what happened, but all of the sudden Step says he doesn't want to settle anymore. I think he might've talked to a lawyer. Joel goes to his desk, sits down. BRIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I say, General Mills isn't going to make their offer official until this settles. Joel considers this. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Step is just chest-beating. He does this all the time. He gets all wound up, talks big, then he always backs down. And that's with his balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bleak looking office with rows of cubicles. We PAN past several cubicles where hardass parole officers meet their parolees -- various gang-bangers, drug dealers, junkies, a hideous transvestite prostitute, etc. As we pa each officer is giving them nothing -- "this is your last chance," "You expect me to believe that?", etc. We contin past officers giving them nothing, giving them nothing, ending on a cubicle with Cindy, where a PAROLE OFFICER is giving Cindy everything -- almost apologetic. PAROLE OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to even bring this up, but you're not living with the drug dealer anymore are you? Cindy's parole officer is a sad schlub of a guy, about 50 with bushy grey hair and a mustache, he has a badge and a on his belt. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. I'm staying at Extended Stay until I can find a place... She smiles, flirtatiously waves her key/card. CINDY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? (SINCERE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really feel like I've turned my life around. Thanks in large part to you. PAROLE OFFICER (ALMOST BLUSHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm just glad to see you're doing so well... Ah, one more thing I just need to ask you: We had a little incident up in Templeton a couple weeks back where someone stole an expensive guitar from a music store? Someone who fit your description. You know anything about that? CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? No... I was probably at work that day.
PAROLE OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Cindy, you realize you can't screw up anymore right? I mean, even something minor, and you could go back to jail for a while this time. I'd hate to see that happen. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yeah, but why would I steal a guitar? I've got no musical talent. I'm tone deaf. They both laugh. PAROLE OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heh heh, So am I. I can't carry a tune to save my life. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Wow... Cindy acts fascinated by Parole Officer's lack of musical talent. He happily goes on about it, forgetting about the guitar... PAROLE OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I could barely sing the Star Spangled Banner in school... DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the workday. People walk to their cars. Joel turns a corner and finds Cindy right in front of him CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mr. Reynolds. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey Cindy. You can just call me Joel. CINDY (FLIRTATIOUS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Joel. So you going to the party tonight? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Right, that's tonight... (AWKWARD) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOEL, (CON T - D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was thinking about it. Are you going? CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, definitely. Maybe I'll see you there? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think I'll probably go. CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have the directions? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure... CINDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, I'll write it down just in CASE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy opens her purse. We see at least FIVE WALLETS, SEVE WATCHES, JEWELRY, etc. She takes out a pen and a piece of pink, girly stationary and starts writing. CINDY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll also put my number on here. In case you want to call me some time -- if you want. Joel blushes awkwardly, like a junior high school kid. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Okay. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel pulls into the driveway and is STARTLED as he practically runs over Nathan, flagging him down. Joel MUTTERS obscenities as he reluctantly stops and roll down the window. NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there. Almost missed ya. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I can't talk right now-- NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I noticed you guys got a new pool cleaner today. How is he? We're thinking of changing services.
JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look Nathan, I gotta... Wait, you mean yesterday, don't you? NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new pool cleaner. You saw him yesterday right? Not today. NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It was today. The new guy. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he look like? NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blonde haired kid, about this high, good looking. Real good looking. IN FACT-- JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it was today? Not yesterday? NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely sure? NATHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know it was today, because I came home for lunch. I was gone all day yesterday. Anyway, you think I could go ahead and get that check from ya? Like I say, it's 55 dollars a plate, so that'd be 110 total. There's no tax... Nathan leans up to scratch his back. Joel seizes the opportunity and pulls away, burning a little rubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel is on his cell phone, yelling in hushed tones at Bra He has the door shut so Suzie won't hear him. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell were you doing at my house today?!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Oh, umm... nothing. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Look, don't worry about it bro'. I won't charge you for this one. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't charge me for...? You had sex with my wife again?!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well, I figured we already did it once, so what's the big deal? I mean, she said to stop by if I was in the neighborhood, so... Besides, I'm not gonna charge you-- JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not gonna charge...? God damn you! Yes you are gonna charge me! I'm gonna pay you! You're not having sex with my wife for free! And I better not ever catch you anywhere near my house ever again! Joel slams down the phone. Then realizes it's a cell phon picks it back up and hits the "End" button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzie is asleep on the couch in her sweatpants. Joel walk through, mumbles something about going to a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel pulls up to the house where the party is going on. H stays in the car, checking it out. Scanning Joel's POV, we see the band, Godscock, playing i the backyard, with Rory on bass. They are set up on the patio of this small two-bedroom suburban house. Most of t people at the party are crowded around the keg, which is the other side of the backyard, ignoring the band. The ba sounds awful -- loud as hell, unmusical, uninspired. The lead singer sings in that awful Eddie Vedder style, but e more loud and overly dramatic. Rory acts all intense, in stark contrast to the non-intensity of the music.

They all have that baggy-shorts tattooed mid-nineties loo It's downright pathetic. There's one drunk guy off to the side banging his head, playing air-guitar and stumbling into the bushes. Joel spots Cindy over by the keg, drinking, mingling. He watches her for a beat, then shakes his head and drives a CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joel sits at the bar talking to Dean, drinking a beer. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe my wife slept with that guy. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I thought you said it wouldn't bother you. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I didn't really think about it long enough... I just wish it hadn't been so easy for him. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm tellin' ya, chicks really go wild for that Brad... (Off Joel's look) Sorry. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're right. He may be a stupid, dull-witted moron, but he can get any girl he wants. Me, I had to work for it. I had to work hard, get a career going, take Suzie out a bunch of times, marry her. But not Brad. He gets to waltz into my house and have sex with my wife just like that. Oh, and by the way? That little prick was at my house again today. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit? What was he doing? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a wild guess.
DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... You pay a guy to do a job, then he comes back and does it for free. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to let him do it for free. No way. I'm paying him. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? How much? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. The same, I guess. Why? DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... So should I get my twenty dollars from Brad then or... Joel shoots Dean an angry look. DEAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can worry about that later... Look at the bright side, now you can call Cindy. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I feel weird about it. Besides, she's at the party, she probably won't be home 'til late. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you need to do? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) I don't wanna do drugs Dean. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know I joke around a lot, but this time I'm serious. (like a doctor) You should try smoking a little pot. It's just an herb, it heals. Stress can kill you, and-- JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get paranoid when I smoke pot.
DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not when you just smoke a little. Come on. You ever meet my friend Willie? Great guy. Really great guy. (as if it's a positive) He's the guy I got that horse tranquilizer from. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIE loads up some kind of giant three-foot tall bong a inhales a massive bong-load. He's a burly ex-football pla type who looks like he might have an extra y-chromosome o two. Joel watches Willie, feeling a little uneasy. Dean pontificates. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been reading about it -- they're making technological advances now, coming up with great drugs that can make you happy and won't leave you with a hangover or nothin'. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding in bong-hit) Right on. Willie finally exhales. The exhale seems to go on way lon than humanly possible, endless amounts of pot-smoke billo out (accomplished with special FX). He finally hands the bong and lighter to Joel. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know... I'm kind of a light weight. I think that's too much for me-- WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still holding out the bong and lighter) Bullshit. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Joel. Don't worry, this stuff isn't that strong. (to Willie, re: Joel) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CON T-D)
dialogues.text: He gets paranoid when he gets too stoned. Joel looks at Willie then at Dean, then takes the bong, partly out of being intimidated by Willie. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, what the hell. Willie instructs Joel on the bong usage in the same condescending way a weight-lifting instructor would. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now this is a gravity bong. Have you ever used one before? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm, I think... no. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, pay attention. Put your thumb right here on the carburetor. When I pull the plunger up and say, "let go" I want you to let go and inhale hard. Joel's POV: Looking down the barrel of the three-foot bon with macho-man Willie holding the lighter at the bowl. WILLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay exhale! JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, maybe I should just let YOU GUYS-- WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to get scary) Bullshit! EXHALE HARD! Mostly out of fear, Joel exhales. Willie puts the bong up Joel's face, lights it and starts lifting the plunger. Th pushes it down. WILLIE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go! Inhale! NOW! Joel lets go of the carburator, inhales. WILLIE (CONT'D) (INSANE)
Joel inhales with all his might, sucking up massive amoun of thick pot smoke as Willie pushes down the plunger. STONER-RIPPLE DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Willie, Dean and Joel sitting around, completely baked -- especially Joel. (We play most of the scene from Joel's stoned, paranoid POV.) Dean makes some kind of barely audible mumble -- or did h JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Long pause. DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Joel's POV: looking from Dean to Willie. Willie sits ther with red eyes barely open. Willie turns slowly to Joel. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought somebody said something. Willie looks at Joel, stone-faced, adding even further to Joel's paranoia. He stares at Joel for a long beat. Then, in an instant, he's right up in Joel's face. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: BWAAAAAAAAAAAH
dialogues.text: Joel jumps back, scared shitless. Willie starts laughing ass off. WILLIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haaaah ha... The look on your face! (INSANE CACKLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man you really do get paranoid when you get stoned. JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake, timid laugh) Yeah, heh heh...
DEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Joel, why don't you call that chick now? JOEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
